'''Dwarf-tossing''', or '''midget-tossing''', is a [[Public house|pub]]/[[Bar (establishment)|bar]] attraction in which people with [[dwarfism]], wearing special padded clothing or Velcro costumes, are thrown onto mattresses or at Velcro-coated walls.<ref>International Dwarf Tossing Association</ref> Participants compete to throw the dwarf the farthest. A related formerly practiced activity was dwarf-bowling, in which a person with dwarfism was placed on a skateboard and used as a bowling ball.<ref>[http://gothamist.com/2008/02/28/dwarf_bowling_o.php Dwarf Bowling on Staten Island Lands in Gutter: Gothamist<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701002832/http://gothamist.com/2008/02/28/dwarf_bowling_o.php |date=1 July 2015 }}</ref> Dwarf Tossing was started in Australia as a form of Pub entertainment in the early 1980s.<ref>[http://www.ozzienews.com/news/is-dwarf-tossing-coming-to-melbourne/ Dwarf Tossing Coming to Melbourne]</ref><ref>[http://twistededge.org/Funny_As_Hell/World_According/Midget_Throwing/ World according to Midget Throwing]</ref>
==Legality==
===Australia=== Commonly thought of as the place where dwarf tossing originated. Laws may prohibit dwarf tossing implicitly, but there are not explicit laws preventing a consenting dwarf from being 'tossed'.
===Canada=== In [[Ontario]], Canada, the Dwarf Tossing Ban Act was introduced in 2003 by [[Windsor West]] [[Member of Provincial Parliament (Ontario)|MPP]] [[Sandra Pupatello]].<ref name="OntLA1">[http://www.ontla.on.ca/web/bills/bills_detail.do?locale=en&BillID=1128 Dwarf Tossing Ban Act, 2003]</ref> This [[private member's bill|private member's public bill]] did not proceed beyond its introduction to second or third readings, nor did it receive royal assent, and therefore died at the close of the 37th [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario|Legislature]].<ref name="OntLA1"/> The bill proposed a fine of not more than $5,000, imprisonment of not more than six months, or both. The bill was hastily advanced in response to a dwarf-tossing contest<ref name="OntLA2">[http://www.ontla.on.ca/house-proceedings/transcripts/files_html/2003-06-12_L025.htm#PARA511 Legislative Assembly of Ontario Transcript of Debates for Thursday, June 12, 2003]</ref> that was held at Leopard's Lounge in [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], Ontario with a dwarf nicknamed "Tripod".<ref name = "GlobeAndMail1">{{cite news |title=Ontario MLA sweats the small stuff |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/incoming/ontario-mla-sweats-the-small-stuff/article1162772/ |author=Canadian Press |authorlink1=Canadian Press |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |location=[[Toronto]] |issn=0319-0714 |date=2003-06-12 |accessdate=17 June 2014 |quote=The organizer of a dwarf-tossing contest vowed the show would go on Thursday even as an angry Ontario politician made an 11th-hour bid to stop the event. |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->}}</ref>
===France=== The [[mayor]] of the small French town of [[Morsang-sur-Orge]] prohibited dwarf-tossing. The case went through the appeal chain of administrative courts to the ''[[Council of State (France)|Conseil d'État]]'', which found that an administrative authority could legally prohibit dwarf-tossing on grounds that the activity did not respect human [[dignity]] and was thus contrary to public order.<ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichJuriAdmin.do?oldAction=rechJuriAdmin&idTexte=CETATEXT000007877723 Conseil d'État statuant au contentieux, n°136727, lecture du 27 octobre 1995]</ref> The question raised legal questions as to what was admissible as a motive for an administrative authority to ban an activity for motives of public order, especially as the ''conseil'' did not want to include "public morality" in public order. The ruling was taken by the full assembly and not a smaller panel—proof of the difficulty of the question.<ref>[http://www.conseil-etat.fr/fr/presentation-des-grands-arrets/27-octobre-1995-commune-de-morsang-sur-orge.html Commentary] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927062531/http://www.conseil-etat.fr/fr/presentation-des-grands-arrets/27-octobre-1995-commune-de-morsang-sur-orge.html |date=27 September 2011 }} of the ruling on the Conseil d'État's site</ref> The ''conseil'' ruled similarly in another case between an entertainment company and the city of [[Aix-en-Provence]].<ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichJuriAdmin.do?oldAction=rechJuriAdmin&idTexte=CETATEXT000007882056& Conseil d'État statuant au contentieux, n°143578, lecture du 27 octobre 1995]</ref>
The United Nations Human Rights Committee decided on July 26, 2002, that the ban was not discriminatory with respect to dwarfs. It ruled that the ban could be considered as "necessary to protect public order, which brings into play considerations of human dignity".<ref>http://juris.ohchr.org/Search/Details/1010</ref>
Nevertheless, dwarf-tossing is not prohibited outright in France. The ''Conseil d'État'' decided that a public authority could use gross infringement on human dignity as a motive of public order to cancel a spectacle, and that dwarf-tossing constituted such a gross infringement. However, it is up to individual authorities to make specific decisions regarding prohibition.
===United States=== Robert and Angela Van Etten, [[Florida]] members of the [[Little People of America]], convinced the state's legislators in 1989 that dwarf-tossing be made illegal. A measure banning dwarf-tossing was passed by a wide margin.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2001_Dec_10/ai_80677114/ Florida Ban on Dwarf Tossing Must Be Upheld, Announces LPA, Inc.; Dwarf-Tossing is a Dangerous, Demoralizing Activity That Poses Specific Hazards to Persons with Dwarfism]</ref> [[New York (state)|New York]] later followed suit.<ref>[http://twistededge.org/Funny_As_Hell/World_According/Midget_Throwing/ Midget Throwing: A Lost Art]</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-25/news/mn-1001_1_dwarf-tossing |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Cuomo Signs Bill to Ban Dwarf Tossing |date=July 25, 1990}}</ref>
In 2001, Dave Flood, who appeared on the MJ Morning Show as "Dave the Dwarf," filed a lawsuit seeking to overturn the 1989 law allowing the state to fine or revoke the [[liquor license]] of a bar that allows dwarf-tossing. The pastime was popular in some Florida bars in the late 1980s.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lQFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r1UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1342,4094341 "Florida Radio Personality Files Suit to Allow Return of 'Dwarf Tossing'"]. ''Ludington Daily News'', December 1, 2001.</ref>
In October 2011, [[Ritch Workman]] introduced legislation that would overturn the ban on dwarf-tossing, claiming such a ban to be an "unnecessary burden on the freedom and liberties of people" and "an example of Big Brother government". Although not a personal advocate of the activity, Workman stated "if a little person wants to make a fool out of themselves for money, they should have the same right to do so as any average sized person".<ref name="PBP dwarves">{{cite news |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/cerabino-lawmaker-wants-state-to-reinstate-dwarf-tossing-1898183.html |work=The Palm Beach Post |first=Frank |last=Cerabino |title=Lawmaker Wants State to Reinstate Dwarf Tossing |date=2011-10-05}}</ref>

'''Fairfield Materials Management Ltd''' is a [[Manchester]] based [[social enterprise]] that operates a community waste management project at Manchester’s New Smithfield Market focused on minimising waste, and bringing social and environmental benefits to Greater Manchester.<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/about/history.html</ref>
By utilising '[[in-vessel composting]]', Fairfield Materials Management established the UK’s first sustainable [[biodegradable]] [[waste management]] system to operate on a wholesale market,<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/about.html</ref> diverted 16,500 tonnes of organic market waste material away from [[landfill]] between 2003 and 2008.<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/what_we_do.html</ref>
Fairfield has developed a composting production model that processes fruit, vegetable, plant and woody waste into [[peat]]-free, [[British Standards Institution]] PAS 100<ref>http://www.wrap.org.uk/composting/compost_ specifications/bsi_pas_100/bsi_pas_100_1. </ref> accredited compost.<ref>http://www.letsrecycle.com/materials/composting/news.jsp?story=5785</ref> It operates on a site fully licensed by the [[Environment Agency]].<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/about.html</ref>
In 2003 Fairfield was recognised as the most innovative social enterprise within its sector by The Composting Association.<ref>http://www.compostingconference.com/Community_Init_Award.html</ref>
==History== Fairfield Materials Management was founded in 2003 by a small group of ecological activists, horticulturists and social entrepreneurs.<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/about.html</ref>
Fairfield Materials Management was initiated by Val Rawlinson (Director) after she became involved in an East Manchester anti-incineration campaign in 1996. The incinerator was not built, but Lucy Danger and Val Rawlinson realised that they had to show Manchester that environmental and social alternatives were available and working successfully throughout the United Kingdom and so Fairfield Composting was established by Val who began promoting home composting and supplying compost bins.<ref>http://www.debdale-eco-centre.com</ref> and Lucy set up EMERGE Recycling recruiting Val as a director.
Val also recognised the need for a commercial sized composting system for New Smithfield Market and choose a Vertical Composting Unit (VCU) system as the preferred technology; Emma Smith was recruited as a waste auditor in November 2001 to undertake a waste composition analysis of Smithfield Market's waste. Chris Walsh joined the team and between 2001 and 2003 the group secured several hundred thousand pounds through grants and loans,<ref>http://www.adventurecapitalfund.org.uk/content/view/28/59/</ref> designed the site, obtaining planning permission and a waste management licence.<ref>http://www.communitycompost.org/hotrotters/fmm.htm</ref>
In 2003 Fairfield began operating and initially diverted waste from four market traders, taking in [[green waste]] from [[Manchester City Council]] and producing compost. In 2004 a further two composting units were added and in 2005 a final three units were added to the system. This enabled Fairfield to process all of the market's fruit and vegetable waste through the in-situ technology.<ref>http://www.fairfieldcompost.co.uk/about/history.html</ref> Whilst remaining a director of Fairfield Val set up Debdale Eco Centre(DEC) and with Emma's help secured funding to promote home composting. WRAP funding later enabled DEC to run a project supplying low cost compost bins which achieved high home composting levels. When Manchester City Council working in partnership with BIFFA introduced the Green Bin home composting levels were reduced negating the work undertaken by Val. Val retired from DEC aged 70 in 2010 but continues as a Director of Fairfield
The business became sustainable through the efforts of Ian Trippier who was recruited as office manager bringing his vast experience of social enterprises and business acumen to the organisation. Ian and Eric Lowry, Operations Manager, have proved an invaluable partnership raising standards in Waste Management and turning Fairfield into a very successful organisation.
In 2009 the Fairfield Group in partnership national [[renewable energy]] business Bio Group Ltd <ref>http://www.crainsmanchesterbusiness.co.uk/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090106/FREE/301069997/1046/energy</ref> secured planning permission in [[Bredbury]], [[Stockport]] for their second waste management site.<ref>http://www.englandsnorthwest.com/invest/news/archive/8162-food-recycle-plant-approved.html</ref>

The '''feminist pathways perspective''' is a feminist perspective of [[criminology]] which suggests victimization throughout the life course is a key risk factor for women's entry into offending.<ref name=":0">Davidson, Janet T. (2009). “Gender and Crime.” In ''21st Century Criminology: A Reference'' Handbook, edited by J. Miller. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.[http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/sagetfccrim/gender_and_crime/0 (http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/sagetfccrim/gender_and_crime/0])</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Belknap|first=Joanne|date=2010|title=Offending Women: A Double Entendre|jstor=25766115|journal=The Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology|volume=100|issue=3|pages=1061–1098}}</ref><ref name=":7" /> {{Feminism sidebar}} == Victimization == {{Main|Victimisation}} Victimization has profound psychological consequences and impacts the social development of an individual.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Macmillan|first=Ross|date=2001|title=Violence and the Life Course: The Consequences of Victimization for Personal and Social Development|url=|journal=Annual Review of Sociology|volume=27|issue=1|pages=1–22|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> There is considerable evidence that victimization is a precursor to involvement in crime.<ref name=":3" /> While victimization is a risk factor for both men and women's criminal behavior, it is a stronger predictor for women.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Cauffman|first=Elizabeth|date=2008|title=Understanding the Female Offender|jstor=20179981|journal=The Future of Children|volume=18|issue=2|pages=119–142}}</ref> Although both men and women may experience victimization in their lifetime, women experience and respond to victimization differently than men due to [[Gender inequality|gender inequalities]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=The Female Offender: Girls, Women, and Crime|last=Chesney-Lind|first=Meda|publisher=Sage Publication|year=1997|isbn=|location=Thousand Oaks|pages=}}</ref> Incarcerated women experience higher rates of victimization than both incarcerated men and the general female population.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Opsal|first=Tara|last2=Foley|first2=Allison|date=2013|title=Making it on the Outside: Understanding Barriers to Women's Post-Incarceration Reintegration|journal=Sociology Compass|volume=7|issue=4|pages=265–277|doi=10.1111/soc4.12026}}</ref>
Women’s imprisonment is frequently attributed to [[Addiction|drug addiction]], [[prostitution]], and retaliation to an abuser.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=DeHart|first=Dana D.|date=2008|title=Pathways to Prison Impact of Victimization in the Lives of Incarcerated Women|url=http://vaw.sagepub.com/content/14/12/1362|journal=Violence Against Women|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1362–1381|doi=10.1177/1077801208327018|pmid=19008544}}</ref> While these attributions are characterized as crimes, research has also begun to conceptualize them as survival strategies to cope with victimization.<ref name=":10" /> A young girl, for example, may run away from an abusive home and turn to prostitution as a way to make a living. Literature on victimization has often created a division between victims and offenders.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Deadman|first=Derek|last2=MacDonald|first2=Ziggy|date=2004|title=Offenders as Victims of Crime?: An Investigation into the Relationship between Criminal Behaviour and Victimization|jstor=3559799|journal=Journal of the Royal Statistical Society|volume=167|issue=1|pages=53–67}}</ref> However, these two groups are not as separate as was once understood.<ref name=":2" />
It was not until the 1970s that research analyzed victimization, traumas, and past abuse as factors that can influence women to commit crimes. In the early 20th century, the personal histories of women in crime were not a focus of research. Early literature suggested women were antisocial due to their biology, environment, and socialization.<ref name=":1" /> [[Cesare Lombroso|Lombroso]], for instance, distinguished female offenders from non-offenders based on their physical anatomies.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Female Offender|last=Lombroso|first=Cesare|last2=Ferrero|first2=Guglielmo|last3=Morrison|first3=William Douglas|publisher=D. Appleton & Company|year=1895|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> These early explanatory factors were understood [[Individualistic culture|individualistically]] outside of a [[Social environment|social-historical context]].
=== Connection to criminal activity === There is a well-documented association between criminal behavior and victimization among female offenders.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> That said, the age and gendered patterns of victimization risk, context, and consequences are highly visible and exacerbated among incarcerated women. There is evidence to support that women involved with crime often have extensive histories of physical and sexual abuse.<ref name=":4" /> Female offenders are more likely to have been abused than male offenders<ref name=":8" /> and more likely to have been victimized than female non-offenders.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":2" /> A survey of national correctional populations found that over half of female inmates have been physically or sexually abused, compared to fewer than one in five male inmates.<ref name=":0" />
Literature suggests female offenders' victimization often begins at a young age and persists through her lifetime.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Browne|first=Angela|last2=Miller|first2=Brenda|last3=Maguin|first3=Eugene|date=1999|title=Prevalence and Severity of Lifetime Physical and Sexual Victimization Among Incarcerated Women|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160252799000114|journal=International Journal of Law and Psychiatry|volume=22|issue=3–4|pages=301–322|doi=10.1016/S0160-2527(99)00011-4}}</ref> Nearly two thirds of incarcerated women have experienced at least one event of abuse by age eleven.<ref name=":9" /> Ninety-two percent of girls under 18 in the California [[Juvenile court|juvenile justice system]] report having faced emotional, sexual, or physical abuse. Eighty percent of women in prison in the United States have experienced an event of physical or sexual abuse in her lifetime.<ref name=":8" /> This lifetime of violence is "pervasive and severe."<ref name=":9" /> The literature suggests that the prevalence of victimization among incarcerated women and its cumulative impact indicates that victimization is a central factor for women's entry into crime.<ref name=":4" />
== Demographics of victimization == The feminist pathways perspective is not meant to suggest that victimization is unique to women.<ref name=":5" /> Instead, this perspective addresses how gender impacts the experience of victimization, and how this difference in experience paves the path to crime for women. An individual's risk of victimization is shaped by environmental context, social networks, and demographics.<ref name=":3" /> [[Life course approach|Life course researchers]] maintain that people are exposed to violence to various degrees based on their location, socioeconomic circumstance, and lifestyle choices.<ref name=":3" /> According to the lifestyle exposure perspective, sociodemographic traits give rise to lifestyle differences which may put an individual at an increased risk of victimization.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Criminal Victimization in Eight American Cities|last=Hindelang|first=Michael|publisher=Ballinger|year=1976|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=}}</ref> For instance, someone from a low-income neighborhood who spends time in public places at night and among strangers may be more likely to encounter offenders, and therefore at a greater risk of victimization.
=== Age === [[File:Age of victimization chart.png|thumb|Estimated Rates (Per 1,000 Persons 12 Years of Age or Older) of Personal Victimization, By Age (Hindelang 1976)|472x472px]] Age is strongly associated with victimization risk, especially for property and violent crimes.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6" /> Victimization tends to be concentrated early in life.<ref name=":3" /> Young people are significantly more likely to experience violent victimization than older adults.<ref name=":6" /> Victimization risk peaks between ages 16 and 19.<ref name=":6" /> According to the [[National Crime Victimization Survey]], the risk of victimization increases by 8 percent from ages 12 to 15 and 16 to 19.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sourcebook of Criminal Justice Statistics- 1998|last=Bureau of Justice Statistics|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice.|year=1999|isbn=|location=Washington D.C.|pages=}}</ref> The [[Crime opportunity theory|opportunity perspective]] attributes this tendency to the way social activities are structured by age. Young adults are more likely to be in situations where they can be exposed to offenders, or engage in activities where they can be easily targeted.<ref name=":3" />
The young age at which the risk of victimization peaks has significant implications on the psychological and social development of the victim.<ref name=":3" /> Childhood is a [[critical period]] of growth, and child victims, according to the [[Cycle of violence|cycle of violence thesis]], will be more likely to be involved in violent crime in the future.<ref name=":3" /> Thus, victimization during developmental years has the potential to disrupt the normal maturation of an individual, and shape the paths this individual may take– including the pathway to prison.
=== Gender === Gender shapes the risk, context, and consequences of victimization.<ref name=":8" /> According to government statistics, with the exception of rape, men are more likely than women to be victims of all violent crimes.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=The Gender of Crime|last=Britton|first=Dana|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.|year=2011|isbn=|location=Lanham, MD|pages=82}}</ref> However, women are underrepresented as victims in official data, and are much more likely than men to be targets of certain types of victimization, such as [[rape]] and [[domestic violence]].<ref name=":8" /> Women are more likely to have been victims of [[child abuse]] than men<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Asscher|first=Jessica|last2=Put|first2=Claudia|last3=Stams|first3=Geert Jan J. M.|date=2015|title=Gender Differences in the Impact of Abuse and Neglect Victimization on Adolescent Offending Behavior|journal=Journal of Family Violence|volume=30|issue=2|pages=215–225|doi=10.1007/s10896-014-9668-4|pmid=25663744|pmc=4315896}}</ref> and more likely to have experienced abuse at an early age.<ref name=":5" />
The way victimization is gendered also impacts how women experience and respond to their victimization. Although victimization during childhood or adolescence is a predictor for female and male offending, the literature suggests it is a stronger predictor for females.<ref name=":10" /> Researchers provides multiple explanations for why victimization has such a prominent effect on women’s future delinquency. Girls grow up in what [[Meda Chesney-Lind|Chesney-Lind]] describes as a “different world”<ref name=":5" /> than boys, and therefore experience a different form of [[socialization]]. Feminist criminologists argue that women adapt to traumas differently than men due to gender inequalities.<ref name=":5" /> Women tend to have limited opportunities to cope with stress openly.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dornfeld|first=Maude|last2=Kruttschnitt|first2=Candace|date=1992|title=Do the Stereotypes Fit? Mapping Gender-Specific Outcomes and Risk Factors|url=|journal=Criminology|language=|volume=30|issue=3|pages=397–420|doi=10.1111/j.1745-9125.1992.tb01110.x|issn=}}</ref> Instead, it is thought that women internalize traumas as feelings of worthlessness, fear, or distress.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":4" /> As a result, the negative effect of stressors is magnified in women.<ref name=":10" /> The literature proposes that gendered expectations and gender roles also shape how traumas impact women differently than men.<ref name=":5" /> For instance, society teaches women that they are values by the strength of their [[Social network|familial and social networks]]. That said, poor interpersonal relationships are a stronger risk factor for female offending than male offending.<ref name=":10" /> Trauma theorists argue that traumas are rarely treated professionally.<ref name=":0" /> Women, therefore, may adapt to victimization by turning to activities or substances, like drugs, that are considered criminal.<ref name=":0" /> These crimes can be framed as coping strategies.<ref name=":10" />
=== Polyvictimization === Polyvictimization refers to experiencing different and simultaneous episodes of victimization.<ref name=":4" /> Most incarcerated women who have experienced victimization have survived multiple traumas over a lifespan.<ref name=":4" /> These repeated traumas have an aggregate impact.<ref name=":4" /> A disproportionally high number of all victimizations account for polyvictimizations.<ref name=":2" /> Women are more likely to be polyvictimized than men.<ref name=":4" /> This is likely because females are more likely to be abused than males, and find themselves in abusive relationships from childhood to adulthood.<ref name=":11" />
Research has recognized both the prevalence and mounting consequences of repeat victimization. Polyvictimization can disrupt multiple relationships and aspects of a woman’s life.<ref name=":4" /> The ripple effects of these disruptions can push a woman off the "path of normalcy."<ref name=":4" /> There is evidence that unrelenting traumas in the early stages of a young girl’s life can lead her to act criminally or "out of the mainstream"<ref name=":4" />
=== Main Routes from Victimization to Crime === Women's victimization has both direct and indirect effects that relate to women's criminal behavior.<ref name=":4" /> Among the many traumas female offenders experience in a lifetime, child abuse and partner abuse have well-documented associations with female criminal behavior.<ref name=":4" />
==== Child abuse ==== [[File:Sample Pathways From Victimization to Crime.png|thumb|Sample pathways from child abuse to crime. Inspired by DeHart (2008).|470x470px]] Female [[Juvenile delinquency|juvenile delinquents]] are more frequently victims of sexual or physical abuse than male juvenile delinquents.<ref name=":11" /> Eighty-two percent of the incarcerated women interviewed by Browne, Miller, and Maguin<ref name=":9" /> at the [[Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women|Bedford Hills Maximum Security Correctional Facility]] were abused during childhood, and nearly 60 percent had been sexually abused by a parental figure.<ref name=":9" /> Research suggests that girls experience [[child abuse]]– both physical and sexual –differently than boys.<ref name=":11" /> For instance, girls are more likely to have experienced penetrative abuse and less likely to have been physically abused.<ref name=":11" />
Childhood victimization is a strong predictor of future criminal behavior and future mental health issues.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anumba|first=Natalie|last2=Dematteo|first2=David|last3=Heilbrun|first3=Kirk|date=2012|title=Social Functioning, Victimization, and Mental Health among Female Offenders|url=http://cjb.sagepub.com/content/39/9/1204|journal=Criminal Justice and Behavior|volume=39|issue=9|pages=1204–1218|doi=10.1177/0093854812443489}}</ref> Given the gender differences in child abuse experience, the association between child abuse and delinquency is also distinct for males and females. According to data collected from the Washington State Court Juvenile Assessment data, physical child abuse is a strong predictor of women's violent behavior.<ref name=":11" /> However, there is little research on the specific mechanism that links childhood victimization and delinquent behavior.<ref name=":4" />
Feminist criminologists understand childhood victimization as a structured theme throughout the lives of incarcerated women. The long-term effects of childhood victimization are essential to understanding how women become incarcerated. For some women, childhood victimization directly relates to their involvement in crime.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title=Compelled to Crime: The Gender Entrapment of Battered Black Women|last=Richie|first=Beth|publisher=Routledge|year=1996|isbn=|location=London|pages=5}}</ref> In these situations, children may be "missocialized" by caregivers who offer them drugs, force them to steal, or exploit them as prostitutes.<ref name=":4" />
[[Child abuse|Childhood victimization]] also has indirect links to future offending. There is evidence that girls from abusive households are more at risk to run away before adulthood, therefore subjecting themselves to an increased risk of becoming involved with drugs or prostitution.<ref name=":9" /> The majority of female juvenile offenders report that their first arrest was for running away from an abusive home.<ref name=":4" /> [[Prostitution]], [[property crime]]s, and [[Illegal drug trade|drug distribution]] become means of survival for young female runaways.<ref name=":4" /> Additionally, women who were physically or sexually abused as children by caretakers have a significantly higher risk of drug abuse and addiction.<ref name=":9" /> Some young women become dependent on drugs to desensitize themselves from their traumatic histories.<ref name=":4" /> Women's involvement in drugs or [[prostitution]] then significantly increases their chances of arrest or incarceration.<ref name=":0" />
==== Partner abuse ==== Studies have observed large numbers of incarcerated women who experienced [[intimate partner violence]] prior to incarceration.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /><ref name=":14" /> Seventy-five percent of the women studied by Browne, Miller, and Maguin<ref name=":9" /> at the [[Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women|Bedford Hills Maximum Security Correctional Facility]] reported histories of partner abuse. Rates of partner abuse among female offenders are higher than those among male offenders.<ref name=":15">Harlow, Caroline Wolf. (1999). ''Prior Abuse Reported by Inmates and Probationers (Report No. NCJ 172879)''. Washington, DC: Bureau of Justice Statistics, U.S. Department of Justice.</ref> A national correctional population survey from 1999 found that 61.3 percent of women had been abused by an intimate partner prior to incarceration, compared to only 5.9 percent of men.<ref name=":15" /> Research on incarcerated women suggests there is an association between childhood sexual assault and adulthood sexual assault.<ref name=":17" /> This suggests that a lifetime of victimization is characteristic of the female offender.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Raj|first=Anita|last2=Rose|first2=Jennifer|last3=Decker|first3=Michele R.|last4=Rosengard|first4=Cynthia|last5=Hebert|first5=Megan R.|last6=Stein|first6=Michael|last7=Clarke|first7=Jennifer G.|date=2008|title=Prevalence and Patterns of Sexual Assault Across the Life Span Among Incarcerated Women|url=http://vaw.sagepub.com/content/14/5/528|journal=Violence Against Women|language=en|volume=14|issue=5|pages=528–541|doi=10.1177/1077801208315528|issn=|pmid=18408171}}</ref> Partner abuse is common within this lifetime of victimization.<ref name=":9" /> Intimate partner violence has both direct and indirect implications for a woman's entry into crime.
Some feminist criminologists suggest that partner abuse coerces, if not forces, women to become involved in crime.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":14" /> In these situations, an abusive partner may entrap a woman into crime.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vawnet.org|title=Women's Experiences of Abuse as a Risk Factor for Incarceration|last=Gilfus|first=Mary|date=2002|website=|publisher=VAWnet: A Project of the National Resource Center on Domestic Violence/Pennsylvania Coalition Against Domestic Violence|access-date=}}</ref> There is evidence that incarcerated women were forced by their partners– through physical attacks or threats –to commit murders, robbery, check fraud,<ref name=":4" /> and sell or carry drugs.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":16" /> Richie observed this gender entrapment among battered African-American women in New York City jails, whom she described as being "compelled to crime."<ref name=":13" /> [[Economic abuse|Financially abusive]] partners may manipulate women into debt until they are left with no resources, and as a result, are more likely to turn to criminal activities to support themselves.<ref name=":16" />
Partner abuse also has indirect effects on the pathway to crime. There is evidence that women are sometimes implicated for crimes related to their partner abuse.<ref name=":4" /> Some women, for example, retaliated against their abuser and were imprisoned for homicide-related charges.<ref name=":4" /> Some women were implicated in the abuse of their children, who were also harmed by the abusive partner.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /> Research also finds that victims of intimate partner violence are likely to be involved with drugs.<ref name=":16" /> Drugs are either introduced by the abuser,<ref name=":16" /> or they become a self-medicated coping mechanism.<ref name=":4" /> Abusive partners sometimes isolate a woman from her social networks, thus structurally dislocating her from all legitimate institutions, such as family.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arnold|first=Regina|date=1990|title=Processes of Victimization and Criminalization of Black Women|jstor=29766565|journal=Social Justice|volume=17.3|issue=41|pages=153–166|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> Women reported feeling a sense of rejection and worthlessness as a result of this isolation, and often coped by using drugs.<ref name=":4" /> Battered women are surrounded by extreme stress and can become dependent on these substances.<ref name=":16" /> Obtaining drugs puts these women at an increased risk of arrest.<ref name=":16" />
== Critique of the victimization explanation ==
=== Women's agency ===
The feminist perspective on crime is sometimes criticized for overemphasizing or disregarding women's agency.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sexed Work: Gender, Race, and Resistance in a Brooklyn Drug Market|last=Maher|first=Lisa|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=Oxford|pages=}}</ref> Traditional feminist approaches to women in crime often overlook women's locations in society and place too much emphasis on women's individual choices.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Criminology|last=Schram|first=Pamela|last2=Tibbetts|first2=Stephen|publisher=Sage Publication|year=2014|isbn=978-1-4833-0228-7|location=Thousand Oaks|pages=307–309|chapter=Chapter 11: Feminist Theories of Crime}}</ref> This paints female offenders as active participants who are compelled to act criminally. In contrast, some research strips women of their agency and portrays them as "passive victims of oppressive social structures, relations, and substances, or some combination thereof."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Invisible Woman: Gender, Crime, and Justice|last=Belknap|first=Joanne|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2015|isbn=|location=Stamford|pages=}}</ref> This portrayal perpetuates the notion that women are always submissive to social structures.<ref name=":12" /> Critics hold that it is essential for research on women in crime to consider both the social-historical context and the woman's individual motivations.
=== Intersectionality ===
Although the feminist pathways perspective attempts to differentiate the experience of men and women in crime, it does not take into account the complex factors that also impact a woman's experiences and histories, such as race and class.<ref name=":12" /> Some critics argue that a "feminist" perspective too often only considers the experiences of a white, middle-class woman.<ref name=":12" /> Just as gender acts as an organizing principle in society, race and class also shape opportunity structures and social positions.<ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Gender Through the Prism of Difference|last=Zinn|first=Maxine Baca|last2=Hondagneu-Sotelo|first2=Pierrette|last3=Denissen|first3=Amy|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> A suburban upper-class, white woman, for instance, will likely encounter different forms of victimization in her lifetime than a lower-income, African American woman who lives in a crime-ridden neighborhood. An [[Intersectionality|intersectional]], or interlocking, perspective takes into account that other social identities impact an individual's victimization and path into crime. [[White feminism|Multicultural feminism]] is necessary to fully understand how social identities interact with traumatic life course events to pave the way to prison.
=== Separating offenders and victims ===
Feminist scholars have strongly discouraged researchers from portraying female offenders and victims as mutually exclusive groups.<ref name=":12" /> Instead, critics argue the line between them should be blurred because women's involvement in crime is so often linked to their subordinate social positions, which make them vulnerable to victimization.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Gilfus|first=Mary|date=1993|title=From Victims to Survivors to Offenders|journal=Women & Criminal Justice|volume=4|issue=1|pages=63–89|doi=10.1300/J012v04n01_04|issn=}}</ref><ref name=":12" /> Critics hold that women can only be understood as criminals if they are also understood as victims, necessitating fluidity between offenders and victims.<ref name=":12" />

[[File:Sample 09-F9 protest art, Free Speech Flag by John Marcotte.svg|thumb|right|225px|[[Free Speech flag]], from the [[AACS encryption key controversy|HD DVD AACS]] case.]] '''Freedom of information''' is an extension of [[freedom of speech]], a fundamental [[human right]] recognized in [[international human rights law|international law]], which is today understood more generally as [[freedom of expression]] in any medium, be it orally, in writing, print, through the [[Internet]] or through art forms.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} This means that the protection of freedom of speech as a right includes not only the content, but also the means of expression.Andrew Puddephatt, Freedom of Expression, The essentials of Human Rights, Hodder Arnold, 2005, pg.128 Freedom of information also refers to the [[right to privacy]] in the content of the [[Internet]] and [[information technology]]. As with the right to freedom of expression, the [[right to privacy]] is a recognised [[human right]] and freedom of information acts as an extension to this right.[http://freenetproject.org/papers/freenet-ieee.pdf Protecting Free Expression Online with Freenet - Internet Computing, IEEE] Lastly, freedom of information can include [[criticism of patents|opposition to patents]], [[Criticism of copyright|opposition to copyrights]] or [[criticism of intellectual property|opposition to intellectual property]] in general.{{cite journal |url=http://somerandomnerd.com/node/647|title=Freedom of Information vs. Protection of Intellectual Property}} The [[Pirate Parties International|international]] and [[United States Pirate Party]] have established political platforms based largely on freedom of information issues.{{cite journal |title=Avast Network, What is the Pirate Party—and why is it helping Wikileaks?|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/world/81963/pirate-party-wikileaks}} ==In law== In June 2006 nearly 70 countries had freedom of information legislations applying to information held by government bodies and in certain circumstances to private bodies. In 19 of these countries the freedom of information legislation also applied to private bodies.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=211 & 223|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} Access to information was increasingly recognised as a prerequisite for transparency and accountability of governments, as facilitating consumers' ability to make informed choices, and as safeguarding citizens against mismanagement and corruption. This has led an increasing number of countries to enact freedom of information legislation in the past 10 years.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=213|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} In recent years, private bodies have started to perform functions which were previously carried out by public bodies. Privatisation and de-regulation saw banks, telecommunications companies, hospitals and universities being run by private entities, leading to demands for the extension of freedom of information legislation to cover private bodies.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=222|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} === Government bodies === As of 2006, 70 countries had comprehensive freedom of information legislation for public bodies, nearly half of which had been enacted in the past 10 years. Such legislation was pending in a further 50 countries. === Private bodies === As of 2006, the following 19 countries had freedom of information legislation that extended to government bodies and private bodies: [[Antigua and Barbuda]], [[Angola]], [[Armenia]], [[Colombia]], the [[Czech Republic]], the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Iceland]], [[Liechtenstein]], [[Panama]], [[Poland]], [[Peru]], [[South Africa]], [[Turkey]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Slovakia]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. The degree to which private bodies are covered under freedom of information legislation varies, in Angola, Armenia and Peru the legislation only applies to private companies that perform what are considered to be public functions. In the Czech Republic, the Dominican Republic, Finland, Trinidad and Tobago, Slovakia, Poland and Iceland private bodies that receive public funding are subject to freedom of information legislation. Freedom of information legislation in Estonia, France and UK covers private bodies in certain sectors.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=223|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} In South Africa the access provisions of the Promotion of Access to Information Act have been used by individuals to establish why their loan application has been denied. The access provisions have also been used by minority shareholders in private companies and environmental groups, who were seeking information on the potential environmental damage caused by company projects.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=223–224|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} ==== Consumer protection ==== In 1983 the [[United Nations Commission on Transnational Corporations]] adopted the [[United Nations Guidelines for Consumer Protection]] stipulating eight consumer rights, including "consumer access to adequate information to enable making informed choices according to individual wishes and needs". Access to information became regarded as a basic consumer right, and preventive disclosure, i.e. the disclosure of information on threats to human lives, health and safety, began to be emphasized.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=[[Journal of Alternative Perspectives in the Social Sciences]]|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=216|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} ==== Investors ==== Secretive decision making by company directors and corporate scandal led to freedom of information legislation to be published for the benefits of investors. Such legislation was first adopted in Britain in the early 20th century, and later in North America and other countries.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=216–217|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} Disclosure regimes for the benefit of investors regained attention at the beginning of the 21st century as a number of corporate scandals were linked to accounting fraud and company director secrecy.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=219|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} Starting with Enron, the subsequent scandals involving [[Worldcom]], [[Tyco International|Tyco]], [[Adelphia Communications Corporation|Adelphia]] and [[Global Crossing]] prompted the [[US Congress]] to impose new information disclosure obligations on companies with the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] 2002.{{cite journal |last=Mazhar Siraj|first=|title=Exclusion of Private Sector from Freedom of Information Laws: Implications from a Human Rights Perspective|journal=Journal of Alternative Perspectives on Social Sciences|year=2010|volume=2|number=1|pages=220|url=http://www.japss.org/upload/11._Mazhar%5B1%5D.pdf}} ==Internet and information technology== Freedom of information (or information freedom) also refers to the protection of the right to [[freedom of expression]] with regard to the [[Internet]] and [[information technology]]. Freedom of information may also concern [[censorship]] in an information technology context, i.e. the ability to access [[Web content]], without [[censorship]] or [[digital rights|restrictions]]. === The Information Society and freedom of expression === The [[World Summit on the Information Society]] (WSIS) Declaration of Principles adopted in 2003 reaffirms [[democracy]] and the universality, indivisibility and interdependence of all [[human rights]] and fundamental freedoms. The Declaration also makes specific reference to the importance of the right to [[freedom of expression]] for the "[[information society|Information Society]]" in stating:
We reaffirm, as an essential foundation of the [[information society|Information Society]], and as outlined in Article 19 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], that everyone has the right to [[Freedom of speech|freedom of opinion and expression]]; that this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers. Communication is a fundamental social process, a basic human need and the foundation of all social organisation. It is central to the Information Society. Everyone, everywhere should have the opportunity to participate and no one should be excluded from the benefits the Information Society offers.{{Cite book | last1 = Klang | first1 = Mathias| last2 = Murray| first2 = Andrew| title = Human Rights in the Digital Age | year = 2005| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=USksfqPjwhUC&dq=%22digital+rights%22+human+rights&cad=0| publisher = Routledge |page=1 }}
The 2004 WSIS Declaration of Principles also acknowledged that "it is necessary to prevent the use of information resources and technologies for criminal and terrorist purposes, while respecting human rights".{{Cite book | last1 = Klang | first1 = Mathias| last2 = Murray| first2 = Andrew| title = Human Rights in the Digital Age | year = 2005| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=USksfqPjwhUC&dq=%22digital+rights%22+human+rights&cad=0| publisher = Routledge |page=2 }} Wolfgang Benedek comments that the WSIS Declaration only contains a number of references to human rights and does not spell out any procedures or mechanism to assure that human rights are considered in practice.{{cite book |title=Internet Governance and the Information Society |last=Benedek |first=Wolfgang |author2=Veronika Bauer |author3=Matthias Kettemann |year=2008 |publisher= Eleven International Publishing |location= |isbn=90-77596-56-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ie7Yqiw85TcC&vq=%22Internet+Bill+of+rights%22&dq=%22digital+rights%22+%22human+rights%22&cad=0 |page=36 }} === Hacktivismo === {{main|Hacktivismo}} The [[digital rights]] group [[Hacktivismo]], founded in 1999, argues that access to information is a basic [[human right]]. The group's beliefs are described fully in the "Hacktivismo Declaration" which calls for the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (ICCPR) to be applied to the [[Internet]]. The Declaration recalls the duty of member states to the ICCPR to protect the right to [[freedom of expression]] with regard to the internet and in this context freedom of information.http://www.cultdeadcow.com/cDc_files/declaration.html The Hacktivismo Declaration recognises "the importance to fight against human rights abuses with respect to reasonable access to information on the Internet" and calls upon the [[hacker (computer security)|hacker]] community to "study ways and means of circumventing state sponsored [[censorship]] of the internet" and "implement technologies to challenge information rights violations". The Hacktivismo Declaration does, however, recognise that the right to [[freedom of expression]] is subject to limitations, stating "we recognised the right of governments to forbid the publication of properly categorized [[state secrets]], [[child pornography]], and matters related to personal [[privacy]] and [[Privilege (legal ethics)|privilege]], among other accepted restrictions." However, the Hacktivismo Declaration states "but we oppose the use of state power to control access to the works of critics, [[intellectuals]], [[artists]], or religious figures." === Global Network Initiative === On October 29, 2008 the [[Global Network Initiative]] (GNI) was founded upon its "Principles on Freedom of Expression and Privacy". The Initiative was launched in the 60th Anniversary year of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] (UDHR) and is based on internationally recognized laws and standards for [[human rights]] on [[freedom of expression]] and [[privacy]] set out in the UDHR, the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (ICCPR) and the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] (ICESCR).[http://www.globalnetworkinitiative.org/faq/index.php Global Network Initiative, FAQ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309234331/http://www.globalnetworkinitiative.org/faq/index.php |date=2009-03-09 }} Participants in the Initiative include the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Google]], [[Microsoft]], [[Yahoo]], other major companies, human rights NGOs, investors, and academics.[https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/10/29/global20097.htm Internet Rights Protection Initiative Launches] [http://www.globalnetworkinitiative.org/participants/index.php Global Network Initiative, Participants] According to reports [[Cisco Systems]] was invited to the initial discussions but didn't take part in the initiative. [[Harrington Investments]], which proposed that Cisco establish a human rights board, has dismissed the GNI as a voluntary code of conduct not having any impact. Chief executive John Harrington called the GNI "meaningless noise" and instead calls for bylaws to be introduced that force boards of directors to accept human rights responsibilities.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/nov/17/censorship-internet |title=The big business of net censorship |last=Glanville |first=Jo |date=17 November 2008 |publisher= The Guardian | location=London}} === Internet censorship === {{main|Internet censorship}} Jo Glanville, editor of the [[Index on Censorship]], states that "the internet has been a revolution for censorship as much as for free speech". The concept of freedom of information has emerged in response to state sponsored censorship, monitoring and surveillance of the internet. Internet censorship includes the control or suppression of the publishing or accessing of information on the [[Internet]]. According to the [[Reporters without Borders]] (RSF) "internet enemy list" the following states engage in pervasive internet censorship: [[Cuba]], [[Iran]], [[Maldives]], [[Myanmar]]/[[Burma]], [[North Korea]], [[Syria]], [[Tunisia]], [[Uzbekistan]] and [[Vietnam]].[http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=19603 List of the 13 Internet enemies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102000000/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=19603 |date=January 2, 2008 }} RSF, 2006 November A widely publicised example is the so-called "[[Great Firewall of China]]" (in reference both to its role as a [[firewall (networking)|network firewall]] and to the ancient [[Great Wall of China]]). The system blocks content by preventing [[IP address]]es from being routed through and consists of standard firewall and [[proxy server]]s at the [[Internet]] [[gateway (telecommunications)|gateway]]s. The system also selectively engages in [[DNS poisoning]] when particular sites are requested. The government does not appear to be systematically examining Internet content, as this appears to be technically impractical.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/china/story/0,,1713317,00.html|title=War of the words |publisher=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | first=Jonathan | last=Watts | date=2006-02-20 | accessdate=2010-05-02}} [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China]] is conducted under a wide variety of laws and administrative regulations. In accordance with these laws, more than sixty Internet regulations have been made by the People's Republic of China (PRC) government, and censorship systems are vigorously implemented by provincial branches of state-owned [[Internet service provider|ISP]]s, business companies, and organizations.{{cite web |url= https://www.hrw.org/reports/2006/china0806/3.htm|title= II. How Censorship Works in China: A Brief Overview|accessdate= 2006-08-30|author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |work= |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] }}[http://www.chinaeclaw.com/english/showCategory.asp?Code=022 Chinese Laws and Regulations Regarding Internet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220052125/http://www.chinaeclaw.com/english/showCategory.asp?Code=022 |date=2012-02-20 }} In 2010, U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]], speaking on behalf of the [[United States]], declared 'we stand for a single internet where all of humanity has equal access to knowledge and ideas'. In her 'Remarks on Internet Freedom' she also draws attention to how 'even in authoritarian countries, information networks are helping people discover new facts and making governments more accountable', while reporting President [[Barack Obama]]'s pronouncement 'the more freely information flows, the stronger societies become'.{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/20092013clinton/rm/2010/01/135519.htm |title=Remarks on Internet Freedom |publisher=US Department of State website |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} == See also == {{BLP refimprove|date=May 2016}} '''Jean Marie Syjuco''' (born June 26, 1952) is a [[Painting|painter]], [[installation artist]], and [[performance artist]] from [[Manila]], [[Philippines]].
Through the 1980s and the 1990s, Jean Marie brought attention and institutional support to the maverick art-form of [[Performance Art]] in the Philippines. Beginning in the 1970s as an extension of her work as a [[visual artist]], her performance works developed from conceptual pieces of marked brevity rooted in anti-narrative devices, to the thematic spectacles and large-scale collaborations and video documentations for which she is now better known.<ref>http://www.aaa.org.hk/Collection/Details/25051</ref>
For over 3 decades, she has balanced her roles as a painter of Abstract and Fantasy genres, sculptor, installation and performance artist. Since she was awarded the ''Gold Medal for Sculpture in the 1980 AAP (Art Institution of the Philippines) Annual Art Competition'', her transmedia objects and installations have occupied a unique place in contemporary art for their [[avant-garde]] melding of folk and technological elements.<ref>{{cite web|last=Castillones |first=Danny |url=http://cuadrofilipino.blogspot.com/2008/04/orphaned-egg-weapons-of-mass.html |title=CuadroFilipino: Weapons of Mass Destruction in Cesare & Jean Marie Syjuco’s Aesthetics |website=Cuadrofilipino.blogspot.com |date=2008-04-24 |accessdate=2016-05-20}}</ref>
Jean Marie Syjuco was a recipient of the 1990 [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] Gawad CCP Para Sa Sining Biswal Award.<ref>http://fineartmanila.com/artists/biography/syjuco</ref>
Currently, she is building the ''New “Art Lab”'', a non-profit developmental art facility (founded with her husband, [[Cesare Syjuco]]), which served as the haven of experimental art in the 1990s. <ref>[http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/89493/a-home-or-a-gallery-or-both]</ref>

{{blp refimprove|date=June 2018}} [[File:Park rzeźby na bródnie bródno 2.jpg|thumb|"Bródno" – Bródno Sculpture Park in Warsaw (Poland)]] '''Jens Haaning''' (born 1965) is a Danish conceptual, contemporary artist living and working in [[Copenhagen]].
Haaning has produced a body of artworks since the 1990s, which – when seen together – offers an acute reflection of a complex and changing society in the West. The works address the existing structures of power and communication in the global society and necessitate a debate around subjects such as migration, displacement, nationalism, and other aspects related to our coexistence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gibca.se/index.php/en/2017/artists-gibca-2017/jens-haaning|title=GIBCA • Jens Haaning|website=www.gibca.se|language=en|access-date=2017-12-08}}</ref>
Often the works consist of interventions in institutional structures or public spaces. Examples of these are: ‘Middelburg Summer 1996’ (1996), which was a temporary relocation of a factory employing immigrant workers to the exhibition space De Vleeshal, Middelburg, The Netherlands, and ‘Turkish Jokes’ (1994) a sound piece with a tape-recording of jokes, told by Turks in their native language, which was originally played in a public square in Oslo, Norway.
==Exhibitions== Haaning has exhibited extensively, the main exhibitions include: [[Documenta11|Documenta XI]], [[Kassel]], Germany (2002), the 9th [[Istanbul Biennial]], [[Istanbul]], Turkey (2005), Traffic at [[CAPC Museé d'art contemporain]], [[Bordeaux]], France (1996), [[Vienna Secession]], [[Vienna]], Austria (1997, 1998, 2007), Publicness at [[Institute of Contemporary Arts|ICA]], [[London]], England (2003), the 6th [[Gwangju Biennale]], [[Gwangju]], South Korea (2002, 2006) and latest a large survey of Haaning’s works from the 1990s until 2017 at Göteborg International Biennial for Contemporary Art, [[Gothenburg]], Sweden (2017).

{{About||the song by Capital Cities|Kangaroo Court (song)|the EP by Ritual|Kangaroo Court (EP)}}
A '''kangaroo court''' is a court that ignores recognized standards of law or justice, and often carries little or no official standing in the territory within which it resides.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/kangaroo%20court| title = kangaroo court |website = Merriam-Webster Dictionary |accessdate = 2011-11-11}}</ref> The term may also apply to a court held by a legitimate judicial authority who intentionally disregards the court's legal or ethical obligations. The defendants in such courts are often denied access to legal representation and in some cases, proper defence.
Prejudicial bias of the decision-maker or from political decree are among the most publicized causes of kangaroo courts.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} Such proceedings are often held to give the appearance of a fair and just trial, even though the verdict was already decided before the trial actually began.
A kangaroo court could also develop when the structure and operation of the forum result in an inferior brand of adjudication. A common example of this is when institutional disputants ("repeat players") have excessive and unfair structural advantages over individual disputants ("one-shot players").<ref>Stempel, Jeffrey W. 8 Nev. L.J. 251 (2007-2008) Keeping Arbitrations from becoming Kangaroo Courts</ref>
==Etymology== The term ''kangaroo court'' is often erroneously believed to have its origin from the courts of Australia's penal colonies.<ref name="Etymology" /> However, the first published instance of the term is from an American source in the year 1853.<ref name=OED>{{cite dictionary|dictionary=Oxford English Dictionary|title=kangaroo court|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> Some sources suggest that it may have been popularized during the [[California Gold Rush]] of 1849, along with ''mustang court'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=kangaroo+court&searchmode=none |title=Kangaroo Court |website=Etymology Online}}</ref> as a description of the hastily carried-out proceedings used to deal with the issue of [[Land claim#Mining claim (United States)|claim jumping]] miners.<ref name=Etymology>{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Cecil|title=What's the origin of "kangaroo court"? Is "kangaroo" aborigine for "I don't know"?|url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/491/whats-the-origin-of-kangaroo-court|publisher=The Straight Dope|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> Ostensibly the term comes from the notion of justice proceeding "by leaps", like a [[kangaroo]]<ref name=brockbond>{{cite web|url=http://www.norwichbulletin.com/sports/x1331803980/Minor-League-Baseball-In-this-court-most-anything-goes#axzz2Nq4oSU1r|archive-date=April 11, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130411120510/http://www.norwichbulletin.com/sports/x1331803980/Minor-League-Baseball-In-this-court-most-anything-goes%23axzz2Nq4oSU1r#axzz2Nq4oSU1r|dead-url=yes|title=Minor League Baseball In this court most anything goes|website=The Bulletin}}</ref> – in other words, "jumping over" (intentionally ignoring) evidence that would be in favour of the defendant. Another possibility is that the phrase could refer to the pouch of a kangaroo, meaning the court is in someone's pocket. The phrase is popular in the UK, US, Australia and New Zealand and is still in common use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Kangaroo+Court |title=Kangaroo Court |website=Legal Dictionary}}</ref>
==As informal proceedings in sports== The term is sometimes used without any negative connotation. For example, many [[Major League Baseball]] and [[Minor League Baseball]] teams have a kangaroo court to punish players for [[error (baseball)|errors]] and other mistakes on the field, as well as for being late for a game or practice, not wearing proper attire to road games, or having a messy locker in the clubhouse. Fines are allotted, and at the end of the year, the money collected is given to [[Charitable organization|charity]]. The organization may also use the money for a team party at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bouton | first = Jim | authorlink = Jim Bouton | title = Ball Four | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] | date = 1990 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 0-02-030665-2 }}</ref>
==Examples== Some examples of adjudication venues described as kangaroo courts are the [[People's Court (Germany)|People's Court]] (Volksgerichtshof) of [[Nazi Germany]] that convicted people who were suspected of being involved with the [[20 July plot#Aftermath|failed plot to assassinate Hitler on July 20, 1944]].
Another example is the trial of [[Pol Pot]] and his brother Ieng San by the [[People's Revolutionary Tribunal (Cambodia)|People's Revolutionary Tribunal]] in [[Cambodia]] in August 1979. After a lengthy trial with a duration of five days, both were sentenced to death ''[[in absentia]]'' on August 19, 1979.<ref name="Schlund-Vials, C. J. 2012">Schlund-Vials, C. J. (2012), ''War, Genocide and Justice'', Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press</ref> Conclusive evidence showed that the verdicts and the sentencing papers had been prepared in advance of the trial.<ref name=chandler>{{cite journal |last= Chandler |first= David |date = 2008|title= Cambodia Deals with its Past: Collective Memory, Demonisation and Induced Amnesia |url = https://doi.org/10.1080/14690760802094933 |language = en |journal = Totalitarian Movements and Political Religions |volume= 9 |issue=2-3 |pages= 355–369 |doi= 10.1080/14690760802094933|access-date= 2018-06-12}}</ref> Relying on this evidence the United Nations proceeded to delegitimize the tribunal stating that it did not comply with standards of international law.<ref name="Schlund-Vials, C. J. 2012"/>
During the [[Romanian Revolution]] in 1989, [[President of Romania|President]] and [[General Secretary of the Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party General Secretary]] [[Nicolae Ceausescu]] and his wife [[Elena Ceausescu|Elena]] were [[Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu|sentenced to death]] by a kangaroo court of soldiers from the [[Romanian People's Army]], which recently switched to the side of the revolutionaries.
